Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SCC-SBE: Research Coordination Network on Leveraging Computational Social Science for Understanding Virtual Organizations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid advances in digitally-enabled communications have given rise to a new organizational form - the virtual organization. Because of their immense capacity for flexibility and their ability to draw on diverse expertise across time and space, the large-scale, cross-boundary collaborations enabled by virtual organizations have the potential to solve some of the grand challenges of today's world - those in environmental sustainability, climate change, disaster response, education, and health care. However, research on understanding and enabling virtual organizations requires the deep expertise of many disciplines including computer science, information and decision sciences, communication, management, and psychology, to name a few. Therefore an integral next step is to invest in community and infrastructure development that better fuses the "social" and the "technical" cores of this research enterprise. This need for greater socio-technical integration is at the heart of a new paradigm which we call computational social science enabled virtual organizational research (CSSeVOR).

This research coordination network will increase the interconnections between scholars across disciplines and catalyze a new community examining virtual organizations using computational and data-enabled approaches. Big data presents an enormous opportunity for organizational science, particularly the areas aimed at understanding human behavior and organizing processes. However, utilizing such data requires a fundamental transformation within the areas of science engaged in this problem domain. This project engages a core set of interdisciplinary scientists representing both the "social" and the "technical" thinking about virtual organizing, to work collaboratively to build the scientific network needed to tackle the challenges of utilizing big data in the organizational sciences, and to set up the necessary conditions for big-data enabled organizational science research to thrive. The project team will conduct workshops, research incubators, doctoral consortia, and a conference to build community and capacity for computational virtual organization research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Research Coordination Network focused on building computational social science capacity into the study of virtual organizations. We call this community computational social science-enabled virtual organizational research (hereafter referred to as CSSeVOR). The national big data initiative coordinates the efforts of multiple agencies and fields to collect, manage, understand, and utilize data from large repositories in order to advance science (Hanovar et al., 2012). This initiative is ushering in extraordinary advances in data collection and curation, advanced analytics, and data infrastructure. Parallel advancements are needed in the social sciences to develop a community of next-generation scientists prepared to capitalize on the insights that can be gained by harnessing opportunities stemming from the big data initiative. The social sciences, which are critical to cracking the code of virtual organizational functioning, are presently ill equipped to capitalize on the unprecedented possibilities offered by big social science data. In response to this deficiency, there has been a robust interest in advancing the notion of computational social science (Lazer et al., 2009). Akin to computational approaches in other disciplines, computational social science leverages the capacity to collect and analyze data at scale to transform the conduct of social science. To build a community for CSSeVOR, this project leveraged the collective expertise of three key constituencies: (1) experts who are leading the way in computational social science, (2) social scientists at the forefront of research on groups and organizations, and (3) leading scientists in computing and analytics. By connecting these three groups toward this common goal, this RCN facilitated data-intensive transformation in the social sciences.

Specifically, this RCN supported a series of professional events to build community and capacity for CSSeVOR. We inaugurated an interdisciplinary doctoral consortium targeted at junior scholars. The first two INGRoup consortia were supported by this RCN, and now this consortia is self-sustaining. We inaugurated a full scale academic conference, IC2S2, on computational social science, that was supported by this RCN for 2 years, and is now self-sustaining.  We convened data science workshops at multiple social science conferences. Lastly, we conducted a specialty workshop on peer production, one of the emerging areas of virtual organizing. Together, these events have enabled us to meet the original aims of our RCN:

  • Build the CSSeVOR Community – Create networks in four areas needed to form a community around virtual organizations.
  • Create more “socio-technical” connections between members of the scholarly communities studying the social and technical aspects of virtual organizational effectiveness.
  • Create more “international” connections between members of the scholarly communities studying virtual organizations, who are doing so from different cultural backgrounds, national contexts, and geographic locations.
  • Strengthen existing connections between members of the socio- and technical- communities. Create a sustaining “core” for the community.
  • Forge connections with new communities that are not currently engaged in the virtual organization problem, but whose expertise is likely to be valuable.
